title: Allergies in the Workplace

content: Since moving to London in 2016, I’ve worked for more than five different companies, each of which had their own policies around food allergies. I’ve put together my top tips and experiences when starting at a new business. Here are some of the things you should be doing to safeguard yourself while at work and to make sure they take your allergy as seriously as possible.

Communication is always key, and discussing your food allergy is so important when starting at a new company. It’s best to practice mentioning your allergy during the interview stage. This can be daunting at first, especially in a high-pressure situation like an interview; however, it’s important that your employers understand the seriousness of your condition. This will also give you a good indication of their existing policies, if any, and how they are willing to adapt to your needs.

Once you've started, it’s important to make the new team members around you aware of your allergies, as a lot of the time people bring in their own snacks from home. In my own  experiences, people have always been super understanding and try to make sure they don't bring that peanut bar into work from now on! They also do not want to be responsible for your allergic reaction.

sections.heading: Find Out Who the First-Aider Is
content: Finding out who the trained first-aider is wasn’t something I really thought about until I moved to a bigger company. They usually have dedicated people who are first-aid trained and know how to use an epinephrine pen correctly. This is definitely a question you can ask during the interview process or on your first day. To be honest, it did make me feel a lot more at ease knowing there were dedicated people with training in case something took a turn for the worse and I was unable to administer the pen myself. Once the team knew about my allergy blog, they even asked me to do a presentation in front of the company to educate everyone about the seriousness of food allergies!

sections.heading: Teach People to Use the Auto-Injector
content: It’s so important that people actually know how to use the epinephrine auto-injector correctly. A lot of the time, people think you stab it into the neck or the arm. Wrong! I found it helpful to order a tester pen and bring it to the office, where I could demonstrate how to use it correctly. With the tester, you can show people the amount of pressure needed for the needle to be activated as well as the correct place to administer it. I’ve found that people are always willing to learn, especially when it's something that could save someone's life. Never hesitate to show people in the office how to use the auto-injector pen, as it could save your life one day.

sections.heading: What to Do About Takeout Food
content: Getting takeout food like pizzas in the office is something everyone looks forward to – unless you have an allergy! Sometimes it can be stressful as you have to be super vocal about your food allergy, especially when it involves a restaurant you have not eaten at before. A lot of the time people want to order Indian or Thai food into the office. I’ve had to tell everyone that if it contains nuts, I won’t be able to eat it and it is dangerous for me to be around. One solution to this was actually creating a spreadsheet with restaurants I could safely eat at. This helps people identify which restaurants they can order from and takes away the pressure of having to shout across the office every time. It also let me be able to participate in the team lunch and not feel as though I couldn't be a part of the free food fun!

sections.heading: Dealing With Birthday Celebrations
content: At one of my workplaces, whenever it’s someone's birthday, one of the employees would usually head out and get a cake and some snacks. In the past, other teams often got snacks and cakes that contained nuts. I had learned to be very vocal and make my co-workers aware. This meant other teams besides my own were aware of my food allergy as well. In my last job, they went out of their way and bought me a nut-free cake which was really nice and thoughtful and meant I could (for once!) have cake.

sections.heading: Be Cautious at the Company Cafeteria
content: Some businesses, usually bigger companies, offer their own catering services in-house. On one occasion when I started a new job, I made people at the company aware about my nut allergy. However, I didn’t feel they took it seriously enough and weren't well-educated about allergies. What was even more shocking was that I had heard a story about a woman with an allergy who once had an allergic reaction at the company because of the catering. In this situation, I decided to bring in my own packed lunches every day to safeguard myself and limit potential risks.
